data.title: How to use libraries in your Animator code
data.description: Can I use/import NPM modules?
data.body:
Unfortunately you can't require node modules directly in code.js, but you can however hook into the Animator component life-cycle events, or even fire your own event from the component and hook into it from your codebase.

TL;DR: the solution is to implement the logic that requires external modules in your host codebase and communicate back and forth with the component via its API.

data.title: Embedding animations in a SquareSpace website
data.description: Can Animator code be embedded onto a SquareSpace website?
data.body:
Yes, Animator components work as long as you're on a SquareSpace plan that supports "Code Blocks" — https://support.squarespace.com/hc/en-us/articles/206543167

I'd recommend following the "HTML + CDN" instructions per the Publish panel — or from the Share Page (the link you get when you publish a project), you can follow the "HTML Embed" instructions.   Enter the snippet we give you into a Square Space "Code Block," and you should be off to the races.

data.title: Deleting vertex in Path Morphing mode
data.description: Is it possible to delete vertex when Path Morphing a slice?
data.body:
We don't have an ETA for this functionality yet, however, if you need to convert one shape into a somewhat different one you could try to:

  1. Create your initial and final shapes in Sketch (or the tool of your choosing).

  2. Copy the SVG codes (usually available in the right-click menu) for each one.

  3. Paste them in a code editor, or even inside your design tool and copy the "Path D" values.

  4. In Animator, place the playhead at the frame where you want your animation to start/end and paste the value from your previous step in the "Path D" property in the timeline.

Depending on how different the start and finish shapes are, the transition effect will of course vary. It might not suit all use-cases but maybe it's worth a try, since it's low-effort and easy to undo if you don't like the end result.


If your initial shape is very different from your final shape, you can try a slightly different approach:

Put the initial "Path D" value in the first frame and then update the “Path D” properties in later frames with “Path D” values from gradually different shapes created in Sketch until you reach your final shape.

data.title: Targeting brightness as a property in your animation
data.description: Is it possible to target brightness as a css style property?
data.body:
Not brightness or luminance per se, but you can target *color* of individual elements (called Fill, underneath the <tag> in the ADD property list). Color can be tweened.

You can also use opacity for clever tricks, e.g. stacking a brighter element underneath a darker element, and reducing the opacity of the top element.

data.title: Generating random numbers
data.description: How can I generate a random number in a range, to use it in a function or an expression?
data.body:
There isn't a built-in helper for that, but you can do something like this in your expression:

= Math.floor($helpers.rand() * (max - min + 1)) + min;

Where max is the maximum value that the random number should take and min is the minimum value.

Note that you can build your own helper if you are planning to use this expression multiple times. Here's a blog post that details how to do it: https://www.haikuforteams.com/blog/helper-functions/

data.title: Website integration best practices
data.description: What are the best practices to incorporate my animation into a website?
data.body:
The best practice is to use React/Angular/Vue & Animator's npm servers, then the npm install flow described on the Share page.

Once a component has been installed in a codebase, it will have a specific version number in the `package.json` file for that codebase.

Every time you press publish in Animator, a new 0.0.x version of your component is available for install.  The most precise way to get an exact version of your project is to communicate the version number you see in the Publish UI to your developer — e.g. 0.0.19.  They can then specify this in their codebase's package.json, run npm install (or yarn install), and they'll have the new Animator component.


You can see that version number in the top-left of the Publish UI:

data.title: Creating a GIF that doesn't loop
data.description: Is there a way to create a gif that doesn't loop?
data.body:
We've tried, and we can recommend using this service https://ezgif.com/loop-count for that purpose.  

They're not affiliated with us and we can't speak for them at all except that their GIF loop-count-changer worked for us.

data.title: Importing existing Lottie files
data.description: Is there a way to import the .json files from https://lottiefiles.com/ and edit / work with them in Animator?
data.body:
Not currently, though this is something we've discussed several times among our team.

The most likely manifestation of this would be the ability to embed, but not to edit Lottie .json files.

data.title: Creating non-rectangular hotspot areas
data.description: Is there any support for creating non-rectangular hotspot areas? E.g. circular shapes or nuanced paths.
data.body:
By default, all Actions are applied to a div container surrounding your elements, which is a rectangular bounding box.

You can try to:

  1. Create an Action (eventHandler) using the UI, e.g. to apply a hover event to one of your elements.

  2. Pop open code mode, and look for two things:
       a.  The id of the event handler you just created (something like "haiku:Blue-Circle-cd15b1f49a409def").
       b.  The place in the template where the id in ^ a is found.

  3. The template element you found in 2b should have children nested inside.  Choose one of these, e.g. an elementName: "path" or elementName: "circle" (depending on which non-rectangular element you want to target), and copy its haiku-id to your clipboard (e.g. "Page-1-44566a19a389e4ae").

  4. Finally, go back to your Action (eventHandler) that you found in 2a, and replace its ID with the ID you found in 3.

In short, this process will point your eventHandler to a new element (a child element, and one that's not a rectangular div) instead of the whole bounding container.

data.title: Animating a Chrome Web store Extension
data.description: Can I implement some animations on my Chrome Web store Extension instead of using a GIF?
data.body:
Yes, definitely possible.  The only time you need to use our servers for production is if you choose to use our CDN and use the vanilla HTML embed, see screenshot:

If you use React, Vue, or Angular, the Animator code is downloaded and bundled with your own bundler (e.g. webpack).  This should be ready to go for a Chrome extension; our servers aren't involved after installing the packages at development-time.

If you're using vanilla Javascript, I recommend using that CDN snippet e.g. as above (except for your project; you can get this snippet from the Publish page under Embed Options > HTML Embed), manually downloading the scripts referred to be src="https://code.haiku.ai..." and cdn.haiku.ai , and just including them locally in your extension, changing those CDN paths to local paths.

data.title: Adding multiple Actions to the same element
data.description: Can I make an element change on the first click and change back on the second?
data.body:
We only support one action per action type per element. 

The most common way to handle this sort of functionality is by registering a boolean (true/false)-valued State that tracks whether the button should be tracking forward or backward. 

Resources

  • https://docs.haikuforteams.com/using-haiku/defining-states.html

  • https://www.haikuforteams.com/blog/understanding-states/

  • https://www.haikuforteams.com/blog/understanding-actions/

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8BEO3Lb_Qdg

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xb3g8T0JLuY


For more, visit our Docs, Help Articles and Learn page.

data.title: Cancel Animator Pro subscription
data.description: How can I cancel my subscription?
data.body:
The best way to downgrade is to go to https://account.haikuforteams.com/  and choosing the option "Downgrade" toward the bottom of the screen.


What happens with my projects if I cancel my subscription?
If you downgrade your account from Pro to Free, your projects will continue to show up on your website or app.  You will even still be able to access your projects inside Animator, though you will not be able to edit them, make subsequent publishes, nor create new projects until you upgrade again to Pro.

data.title: Moving keyframes
data.description: Can I move keyframes to other layers?
data.body:
At the moment you can't move keyframes between layers, but we plan to enable that feature in the future.

As a workaround: 

  1. Double-click the keyframe you want to copy to  open its value editor.

  2. Position the playhead at the moment in time where you wish to copy the keyframe. 

  3. Paste the value to create keyframes in other layers.

data.title: Adobe XD support
data.description: Are there any plans to support Adobe XD?
data.body:
XD support is a possibility.

In October last year XD released their Plugin API, which makes an integration actually possible!

We'll evaluate priority as we plan out our coming months.

data.title: Troubleshooting: Proxy/VPN
data.description: I'm trying to sign into the app, but I keep getting a time-out error. My machine uses Proxy/VPN.
data.body:
You might be able to trigger the proxy settings dialog by disabling your Wi-Fi adapter (or whatever network adapter you’re using), then trying to sign in. It should look like this.

Where are the credentials stored?

Just locally, in an environment file inside your home directory.

data.title: Importing existing React native code
data.description: Is it possible to import existing React native code for modification and re-export?
data.body:
No, you cannot import or modify React Native code with Animator.
 
Our iOS/Android export (via Lottie) will render only animations, no interactive UIs. You _can_ interop with existing React components by creating placeholders, but you can not interact with or edit React components inside the Animator UI — only inside your codebase. 

See this link for more info: http://help.haiku.ai/fundamentals/using-placeholders

data.title: Controlling groups of assets
data.description: Can I control the properties of a group within another group?
data.body:
You can control individual assets within a group, however you cant control groups within a group. For example, if you want to control the Opacity property of the group "3 Message", you will only be able to control it at an object level in the group.


As a workaround, you can try to “Ungroup” the layer (Cmd+Shift+G), regroup it (Cmd+G), then target subgroups directly.

Another option is entering Code Mode via the toggle on the top, locating the group in the component spec, and modifying its properties by hand:

  • In code mode, you can Cmd+F search to find your group by name in the template. It will look like “haiku-title”: “3 Message”  or similar.

  • In that same attributes dictionary, you will see the haiku ID, e.g. "haiku-id": "Group-fd5851dfec1a0a37".

  • If you Cmd+F search for that ID prefixed by haiku:, e.g. haiku:Group-fd5851dfec1a0a37, you should find the property definitions.

When you have no animations on layout properties, the property definitions will either be missing entirely or in shorthand format, like "opacity": 1. The longhand format can be observed on other places where you’ve registered animations and will look something like:

opacity: {
  "0": { edited: true, value: 0 },
  "1000": { curve: "easeInOutQuad", edited: true, value: 0 },
  "2000": { edited: true, value: 1 }
}

After you make changes, Cmd+S to save and check your work.

The keys are timestamps in milliseconds. The edited property tells our system not to overwrite this property with canon when it merges changes from your design file sources. 

The list of supported curve names is here: https://github.com/HaikuTeam/core/tree/master/src/vendor/just-curves/curves. 

And the specification for available layout properties is here: https://github.com/HaikuTeam/core/blob/master/src/api/index.ts#L467-L478. 

You may want to play with layout animations in a simple playground project with items you can target in the timeline to gain a better understanding of the format.

Note: Most of the changes you make in Code Mode are unchecked, so it’s relatively easy to break your project by making a mistake here, and there is no undo after you save changes and switch back to Design Mode. If you’re not confident in playing around in Code Mode, probably best to wait for this feature to land.

data.title: Troubleshooting: The app is very slow
data.description: I'm experiencing delays when trying to animate something.
data.body:
Animator Core (the renderer, which is built on top of web browsers' native DOM + SVG renderers) does not support very large vector graphics.  Normally this manifests as a very slow editing experience.

So, the first thing you should check is if the assets you’re dealing with are incredibly detailed vector graphics. We have seen situations where some SVGs weigh in at 1+ MB. 

You should be able to verify if this might be the issue quickly by inspecting the file size of your slices (there’s a “Show in Finder” three dot context menu item next to your Sketch file in the Library on the right). For a file called Name.sketch, look inside Name.sketch.contents. Typically this will be a couple of KB at most.

It would be good to understand why they’re so big in the first place:

  • Did you create this with a graphics tablet or similar? Some drawing tools emit everything as a custom <path />

  • Which design tool did you use to create your illustration? For example, Illustrator does tend to under-simplify its vector drawings. 

A few things you can try:

  • For any complex vector assets, try converting them to raster (via the design tool where you authored them)

  • Try exporting to Lottie and using lottie-web on your website to see if this speeds things up (Lottie will not support interactivity/code)

  • If your animation is not interactive, you can pre-render it by exporting to mp4 and embedding that video on your website

  • Finally, if it is interactive:  just remember at the end of the day that you're creating software with Animator, which is bound by the performance constraints of the final medium (the browser).  It simply may be that you're trying to push the browser & Animator Core beyond their practical limits, which would require iterating on your design (e.g. reducing the number of elements) to make it work.

data.title: European users: VAT
data.description: Our relationship with VAT
data.body:
Our relationship with VAT:  

As a US-based company with no European subsidiaries or physical presence, Haiku Systems Inc. is not registered for VAT and does not have a VAT number.  No VAT is included in Amount Due on invoices issued by Haiku Systems Inc. Any applicable VAT is to be reversed charged to the Customer.

data.title: Using the timeline as a state machine
data.description: I want to change an element's color via States but it doesn't transition smoothly.
data.body:
The issue you are experiencing is because when you trigger a State transition on a string (e.g. a color), the value of the state does not change until the end of the transition. Hence, you get no animation/transition.

A workaround is to use the timeline as a state machine. That is, to create the animation you want in a portion of the timeline and then use a Click Action to Go To and Play from the keyframe where the animation starts. For example:

https://share.haiku.ai/u/Tina/troubleshootTest (You can fork this project and see how it was made).

In this project, we:

  1. Added a "fill" property to the oval, and gave it a value in frame 30.

  2. In frame 50, gave it a different value/color.

  3. A tween was automatically created in between, but you can change it to any other transition.

  4. Added a Click Action to the button, and used the Go To and Play snippet to have the animation jump to frame 30 when the user clicks on the button.

  5. Added a "Pause" Frame Action on frame 0, so that the animation doesn't play automatically, and a "Stop" Frame Action on frame 50, so that it doesn't loop back to frame 0.


For tutorials, please visit our Learn page.

data.title: How to use the Code Editor
data.description: Instructions on how to use the built-in Code Editor in the app and/or any custom editor of your choice.
data.body:
To use the built-in Code Editor in the app, you need to find the "Design/Code" toggle at the top, and click on CODE.

Keep in mind that since your animation is simply code, you can also edit its file in any editor of your choice (e.g. Atom, Sublime Text, etc.)!

Using custom code editors with Animator

The file you are looking for is located at:

 ~/.haiku/projects/<yourusername>/<yourprojectname>/code/main/code.js  

Remember to replace <yourusername> and <yourprojectname> accordingly. 

You can also access this file easily through the app if you have your project open by clicking on Developer > Open in Finder  or Developer > Open in Terminal  from the top menu.

data.title: Using States in an instance of a subcomponent
data.description: Is there a way to use States in an instance of a subcomponent, while interacting at the component level?
data.body:
Use case

For example, you want to:

  • View a component (e.g. Main), which contains several subcomponents.

  • Without changing that view, change the State of the instances of the subcomponents.

How to

There are two ways to update child component States:

The first is by directly addressing them via the timeline.

Every state of an instantiated component should be exposed as a timeline row:


The second is event-driven. The gist is you can emit custom events from the parent component down to the child component, then update States using e.g. this.setState({...}) in an Action. Read more here.

data.title: Using Actions in an instance of a subcomponent
data.description: Is there a way to use Actions in an instance of a subcomponent, while interacting at the component level?
data.body:
Use case

For example, you want to: 

  • View a component (e.g. Main), which contains subcomponent.

  • Without changing that view, add a "Hover" event  to the instance of the subcomponent.

  • On hover, trigger actions in the instance of the subcomponent.

How to

The best approach to this would be to pipe down custom events handled at the subcomponent level.

e.g. host component action:

this.send('>', 'someEvent');

The root node of the child component can listen on 'someEvent' and do whatever you want at that point.

You can also emit upwards with '<', sideways with '~', or everywhere with '*'. 

To do it: 

  • Click bolt beneath main component in timeline: 

  • Click Add a New Action, and scroll down to add a custom event.

  • Enter your custom event.


Note: These APIs are new/experimental.

Learn more

Read more in our Docs and watch this video tutorial.

data.title: NPM Support
data.description: Can I get my animation as an npm module?
data.body:
Every time you publish your package you are also publishing the code produced with Animator as an npm module! 

You can find instructions about how to install your package in the publish modal or in the share page (https://share.haiku.ai/) of your published project.

data.title: Repeating components
data.description: Is there a way to create a component instance for each object in a list/table?
data.body:
The best way to handle this for now would be to create your table in vanilla React/Angular/Vue, then repeat a component multiple times inside that table. 

You could use the Haiku Developer API to e.g. orchestrate animations or pass in props for each component. 

If you really want to get creative, you could check out using Placeholders , which would allow you to create a component for your table, and separate components for the child elements, then use React to pass the children into the parent via placeholders. 

You can read more about this approach here: https://help.haiku.ai/fundamentals/using-placeholders  

There is currently not a functional way to repeat child elements inside a table entirely inside Animator.
